Soil Storage

Soil Storage.

Geoscientific Model Development, 14(2), 1037–1079. https://doi.org/10.5194/gmd-14-1037-2021

Water balance

Soil storage \(S_s\) \((mm)\) is calculated as:

\[\frac{dS_s}{d_t} = {P}_{eff} − {R}_{l}− {E}_{s}\]

where \({P}_{eff}\) is effective precipitation \((mm/d)\), \({R}_{l}\) is runoff from land \((mm/d)\) and \({E}_{s}\) is the actual evapotranspiration from soil \((mm/d)\).

Note

\({R}_{l}\) is partitioned into (a) fast surface and subsurface runoff \({R}_{s}\), representing direct surface runoff and interflow, and (b) groundwater recharge \({R}_{g}\) according to the heuristic scheme.

Inflows

Effective precipitation \({P}_{eff}\) is is calculated as

\[{P}_{eff} = {P}_{t} − {P}_{sn} + M\]

where \({P}_{t}\) is throughfall \((mm/d)\), \({P}_{sn}\) is snowfall \((mm/d)\) and \(M\) is snow melt \((mm/d)\).

Note

In urban areas (defined from MODIS data) \(50 \%\) of \({P}_{eff}\) is directly turned into \({R}_{l}\). This is known as immediate runoff and is calculated as :

\[{immediate \: runoff} = 0.5 \times {P}_{eff} \times fraction \: of \: build \: up \: area\]

Next, effective precipitation is reduced by the immediate runoff. The resulting effective precipitation used to compute runoff. See function immediate runoff : line 73 -110 in source code.

Outflows

Actual evapotranspiration \({E}_{s}\) from soil \((mm/d)\) is calculated as

\[{E}_{s} = min\biggl(({E}_{pot} - E_c) , ({E}_{pot,max} - E_c) \times \frac{S_s}{S_s,max} \biggr)\]

where \({E}_{pot}\) is potential evapotranspiration \((mm/d)\), \({E}_{c}\) is canopy evaporation \((mm/d)\) and \({S}_{s,max}\) is the maximum soil water content \((mm)\) derived as a product of total available water capacity in the upper meter of the soil 1 and land-cover-specific rooting depth (Table C2 2). The maximum potential evapotranspiration \({E}_{pot,max}\) is set to \(15 (mm/d)\) globally.

Runoff from land \({R}_{l}\) is calculated following Bergström (1995) 3 as

\[R_l = {P}_{eff} \biggl(\frac{S_s}{S_s,max}\biggr)^\Gamma\]

where Gamma is the runoff coefficient (–). This parameter, which varies between 0.1 and 5.0, is used for calibration. Together with soil saturation, it determines the fraction of \({P}_{eff}\) that becomes \({R}_{l}\).

Note

If the sum of \({P}_{eff}\) and \(S_s\) of the previous day exceed \({S_s,max}\), the overflow is added to \({R}_{l}\)

\({R}_{l}\) is partitioned into fast surface and subsurface runoff \({R}_{s}\) according to

\[{R}_{g} = min\biggl({R}_{gmax} , ({f}_{g} \times {R}_{l} \biggr)\]

where \({R}_{gmax}\) is soil-texture-specific maximum groundwater recharge with values of 7, 4.5 and 2.5 mmd−1 for sandy, loamy and clayey soils, respectively, and \({f}_{g}\) is the groundwater recharge factor ranging between 0 and 1. \({f}_{g}\) is determined based on relief, soil texture, aquifer type, and the existence of permafrost or glaciers 4.

Note

If a grid cell is defined as (semi)arid and has coarse (sandy) soil, groundwater recharge will only occur if precipitation exceeds a critical value of 12.5 mmd−1, otherwise the water remains in the soil. The fraction of \({R}_{l}\) that does not recharge the groundwater becomes \({R}_{s}\), which recharges surface water bodies and the river compartment

References

1(1,2)
